{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox cricketer tour biography | playername = Ron Saggers | image = RonSaggersNSW.jpg | country = Australia | fullname = Ronald Arthur Saggers | nickname = | living = | dayofbirth = 15 | monthofbirth = 5 | yearofbirth = 1917 | placeofbirth = [[Marrickville, New South Wales]] | countryofbirth = Australia | dayofdeath = 13 | monthofdeath = 5 | yearofdeath = 1987 | placeofdeath = [[Harbord, New South Wales]] | countryofdeath = Australia | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = | batting = Right-hand [[batsman]] | bowling = | role = Specialist [[wicket-keeper]] | international = true | testdebutdate = 22 July | testdebutyear = 1948 | testdebutagainst = England | lasttestdate = 22 July | lasttestyear = 1948 | lasttestagainst = England | deliveries = | columns = 2 | column1 = [[Test cricket|Tests]] | matches1 = 1 | runs1 = 5 | bat avg1 = 5.00 | 100s/50s1 = 0/0 | top score1 = 5 | deliveries1 = 0 | wickets1 = – | bowl avg1 = – | fivefor1 = – | tenfor1 = – | best bowling1 = – | catches/stumpings1 = 3/0 | column2 = [[First-class cricket|FC]] | matches2 = 17 | runs2 = 209 | bat avg2 = 23.22 | 100s/50s2 = 1/0 | top score2 = 104* | deliveries2 = 0 | wickets2 = n/a | bowl avg2 = n/a | fivefor2 = n/a | tenfor2 = n/a | best bowling2 = n/a | catches/stumpings2 = 23/20 | date = 25 February | year = 2008 | source = }} [[Ron Saggers]] was a member of [[Donald Bradman]]'s famous [[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|Australian cricket team of 1948, which toured England]] and went undefeated in their 34 matches. This unprecedented feat by a Test side touring England earned them the sobriquet ''The Invincibles''. The team's reserve [[wicket-keeper]], Saggers played in only the [[Fourth Test, 1948 Ashes series|Fourth]] of five [[Test cricket|Tests]], due to an injury to first-choice gloveman [[Don Tallon]]. The match was Saggers's Test debut and he scored five in his only [[innings#Cricket|innings]] with the bat and took three catches. Despite being the second-choice gloveman, Saggers conceded [[bye (cricket)|byes]] at a lower rate than Tallon did during the English summer. During the Fourth Test, Saggers conceded only six byes as England amassed a match total of 861, the lowest percentage of byes conceded by Australia in a match during the tour. Despite this, Tallon remained the favoured gloveman, as Bradman deemed him to be faster and more athletic. Bradman rotated the two glovemen during the tour, and Saggers played in 17 of the 31 [[first-class cricket|first-class matches]], taking 23 [[catch (cricket)|catches]] and 20 [[stumping]]s. Due to Australia's powerful batting line-up, Saggers had few opportunities with the bat, scoring 209 runs at an [[batting average|average]] of 23.22, including his only [[century (cricket)|century]] at first-class level, 104 [[not out]] against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]]. == Background == Saggers started the tour as the clear second-choice wicket-keeper, as [[Don Tallon]] had played in each of Australia's 11 Tests since the resumption of cricket after the [[Second World War]],{{cite web | work =Statsguru | title =D Tallon – Tests – Innings by innings list | publisher =Cricinfo | url =http://statserver.cricket.org/guru?sdb=player;playerid=744;class=testplayer;filter=basic;team=0;opposition=0;notopposition=0;season=0;homeaway=0;continent=0;country=0;notcountry=0;groundid=0;startdefault=1941-06-08;start=1941-06-08;enddefault=1971-02-03;end=1971-02-03;tourneyid=0;finals=0;daynight=0;toss=0;scheduledovers=0;scheduleddays=0;innings=0;result=0;followon=0;seriesresult=0;captain=0;keeper=0;dnp=0;recent=;viewtype=aro_list;runslow=;runshigh=;batposition=0;dismissal=0;bowposition=0;ballslow=;ballshigh=;bpof=0;overslow=;overshigh=;conclow=;conchigh=;wicketslow=;wicketshigh=;dismissalslow=;dismissalshigh=;caughtlow=;caughthigh=;caughttype=0;stumpedlow=;stumpedhigh=;csearch=;submit=1;.cgifields=viewtype | accessdate = 2007-07-31 }} while Saggers was yet to make his Test debut. Saggers made his first-class debut shortly before the start of the war, and after the resumption, was regarded as the second in line for Test selection behind Tallon. However, as Australia did not make any substantial tours in the years immediately after the end of hostilities, there was no need to take a reserve gloveman on such trips. However, the trip to England meant more than six months aborad, so a back-up wicketkeeper was needed, and Saggers was selected for his first national squad. == Early tour == Australia traditionally fielded its first-choice team in the tour opener, which was customarily against [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]].{{cite news| title=Gentrifying the game| first=Gideon | last=Haigh| authorlink=Gideon Haigh| url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/295893.html |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |date=26 May 2007| accessdate=2007-06-01}} Accordingly, Tallon was selected as the wicket-keeper for the match. Tallon scored six, made five dismissals and conceded 11 byes as Australia crushed the hosts by an innings and 17 runs.{{cite web|title=Matches, Australia tour of England, Apr-September 1948 |url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/invincibles/engine/series/61329.html |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |accessdate=2008-07-16}}{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/cgi-bin/player_oracle_reveals_results2.cgi?playernumber=830&opponentmatch=exact&playername=John&resulttype=All&matchtype=All&teammatch=exact&startwicket=&homeawaytype=All&opponent=&endwicket=&wicketkeeper=&searchtype=InningsList&endscore=&playermatch=contains&branding=cricketarchive&captain=&endseason=1948&startscore=&team=&startseason=1948 |title = Player Oracle RA Saggers 1948 |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18403.html |title = Worcestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Tallon was then rested and Saggers took his place for the next [[County cricket|county]] match against [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]]. Saggers scored six, took a catch in each innings and conceded only six byes as Australia won by an innings.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18406.html |title = Leicestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Saggers was then rested for the next two matches, against [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] and [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]]. Australia scraped home by four wickets in the former and won by an innings in the latter. Tallon batted steadily with 10, 17 not out and 50 not out, but conceded 35 byes while taking two catches.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18412.html |title = Yorkshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18422.html |title = Surrey v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Tallon was having difficulty with the bounce and movement of the ball in English conditions, and sustained a bruised right finger when he lost sight of a [[Ray Lindwall]] [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncer]] on a misty morning during the Surrey match. He was hit after placing his hand over his face for protection, and the ball ran away for four byes.Perry (2000), p. 197. While Tallon nursed a bruised finger, Saggers played in three successive tour matches. Against [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]], he made two stumpings and took one catch, and was not required to bat as Australia won by an innings. He then played in the match against Essex where Australia scored 721 runs on the first day to set a new world record for the most runs scored in a day of first-class cricket. Saggers made his highest first-class score, 104 [[not out]]—the only first-class [[century (cricket)|century]] of his career—in a [[partnership (cricket)|partnership]] of 166 runs in 65 minutes of batting with [[Sam Loxton]]. This made him the fourth century-maker for the innings after [[Bill Brown (cricketer)|Bill Brown]], Bradman and Loxton.{{ cite web| url=http://content-www.cricinfo.com/statsguru/content/story/242365.html |title=Rubbing their noses in it ||publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |accessdate=2008-04-28}} Of Saggers's innings, former Test batsman [[Jack Fingleton]] said that "he reminded me at times of [[Alan Kippax]] in his artistry. He plays all the strokes."Fingleton, p. 67. Saggers took one catch as Australia won by [[result (cricket)|an innings and 451 runs]], their largest winning margin of the season. He then faced [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]], scoring six runs and taking one catch in another innings victory. Saggers conceded six, eight and 14 byes respectively in the three matches. Up to this point, Saggers had conceded only 34 byes in his four tour matches, while Tallon had conceded 46 in three.N-{{Ref label|Saggers|1|a}} The next match was against the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] at [[Lord's]]. The MCC fielded seven players who went on to represent England in the Tests,N-{{Ref label|MCC|2|a}} and were basically a full-strength Test team, as were Australia, who fielded their first-choice team. It was a chance for players from both countries to gain a psychological advantage ahead of the Test matches, and Tallon was selected ahead of Saggers despite conceding byes at a higher rate in the opening tour matches. Saggers looked on as Tallon conceded 26 byes and Australia won by an innings. There were four more [[county cricket|county fixtures]] before the First Test, against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]], [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]], [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]] and [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]]. Australia drew the first two before winning the latter pair by eight wickets and an innings and 325 runs respectively. Saggers played in all but the Nottinghamshire match. Against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]], Saggers came in at 6/145 and held up his end, making an unbeaten 22 as Australia reached 204. He then completed a stumping and conceded 11 byes as the hosts replied with 182 before the rain-affected match ended in a draw.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18458.html |title = Lancashire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Saggers went without a dismissal and conceded 16 byes as Hampshire made 195 in their first innings. He came to the crease with Australia having scored 98 runs for the loss of seven wickets (7/98) and was last man out for 17, one of only four players to pass five, as Australia made 117 and conceded a first innings lead for the first time in the season.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18473.html |title = Hampshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}{{Cite book | title = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | edition = 1949 | publisher = [[Wisden]] | chapter = Australians in England, 1948 | pages = 226–227 }} He then completed another stumping in the second innings and conceded four byes as Australia recovered to win by eight wickets. Saggers' final opportunity to stake a claim for Test selection was in the match against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]]. He did not concede a bye and took a catch in the first innings. Saggers was not required to bat as Australia [[declaration and forfeiture|declared their innings closed]] at 5/549, and then made three more dismissals and conceded five byes as Australia won by an innings.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18489.html |title = Sussex v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} == Test omission == {{seealso|First Test, 1948 Ashes series|Second Test, 1948 Ashes series|Third Test, 1948 Ashes series}} [[Image:SaggersMcCabeTallon.jpg|left|thumb|290px|Saggers (centre) pictured with [[Stan McCabe]] (left) and [[Don Tallon]] (right) during a country match in 1945.]] In Saggers' last three matches before the First Test, he conceded 36 byes and made six dismissals. In contrast, Tallon conceded 18 byes in his only match and scored 27.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18467.html |title = Nottinghamshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Despite averaging more byes per innings than Saggers during the warm-up matches,N-{{Ref label|Warm|3|a}} Tallon was retained in the Test team. He took four catches and conceded 17 byes as Australia won by eight wickets. Between Tests, Australia played [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]] and Yorkshire, and Tallon was rested for both matches. The first was won by an innings and the second was drawn. Saggers scored four against Northamptonshire and 22 against Yorkshire. After not making a dismissal against Northamptonshire, he took two catches and two stumpings in the latter match. He conceded 14 and 10 byes in the two matches respectively.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18514.html |title = Northamptonshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18526.html |title = Yorkshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Tallon was retained for the Second Test at Lord's, where he scored 53, took three catches and conceded 16 byes as Australia won by 409 runs. A dive to stop a [[Batting (cricket)#Leg glance|leg glance]] resulted in Tallon severely bruising the little finger on his left hand.Perry (2000), p. 200. Nursing his finger injury, Tallon was rested for both tour matches between the Tests, which were against [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] and [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]]. Australia won the matches by ten wickets and an innings respectively. In Tallon's place, Saggers scored 12, completed a catch and made four stumpings while conceding 18 byes against Surrey. In the match against Gloucestershire, Saggers was deprived of an opportunity to bat as Australia amassed 7/774, its highest score of the tour and its second highest ever in England.{{Cite book | title = [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] | edition = 1949 | publisher = [[Wisden]] | chapter = Australians in England, 1948 | pages = 238–239 }} He took two catches, completed three stumpings and conceded 13 byes for the match.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18553.html |title = Surrey v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}}{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18558.html |title = Gloucestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Tallon was retained as the teams then played out a draw in the Third Test at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Manchester]].Lemmon, p. 103. During the match, Tallon conceded 16 byes and dropped [[Denis Compton]] three times as the English batsman went from 50 to 145 not out.Fingleton, pp. 131–137. Tallon's little left finger swelled up after the Third Test and he exacerbated the injury during the next tour match against [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]], which Australia won by ten wickets.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18593.html |title = Middlesex v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} == Test debut == {{main|Fourth Test, 1948 Ashes series}} As a result of Tallon's finger injury, Saggers made his Test debut in the Fourth Test, which started at [[Headingley Stadium|Headingley]] on 22 July 1948. As England made 496 runs in their first innings, Saggers took catches to remove [[Denis Compton]] for 23, caught down the [[leg side]],Fingleton, p. 158. and [[Jim Laker]] for four. During the innings, Saggers was noted by Fingleton for maintaining a quiet presence behind the stumps, whereas Tallon was characteristically known for loudly [[appeal (cricket)|appealing]] in concert with the bowler when he was playing. Fingleton felt that Saggers' failure to appeal dampened the morale of the bowlers, who were vocally supported by Tallon in the other four Tests.Fingleton, p. 152. Australia conceded 496 runs but Saggers leaked only two byes. Australia replied with 458, but Saggers was unable to make a substantial contribution, stumped by England's wicket-keeper [[Godfrey Evans]] off the bowling of Laker for only five runs. England's second innings reached 8/365, as Saggers took one catch to secure the wicket of [[Ken Cranston]] and conceded four byes. This left Australia needing a world record Test run chase of 404 for victory. However, an innings of 182 runs from [[Arthur Morris]] and 173 not out from Bradman meant that Saggers was not required to bat in the second innings; Australia defeated England by seven wickets, and set a world record for the highest successful Test run chase.{{Cite web|title= Fourth Test Match England v Australia |work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]] |year=1949 |url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152897.html |accessdate=2008-07-02 |publisher=[[Wisden]]}} Saggers's six byes out of England's match total of 861 runs was the lowest percentage of byes conceded by Australia in a match on the tour.N-{{Ref label|Australia|4|a}} Saggers made six not out, completed two catches, a stumping and conceded 15 byes in the innings victory over [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]],{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18616.html |title = Derbyshire v Australians |date = 1948-07-28 |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} before being rested in the next match against [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]]. In his first match back from injury, Tallon took a catch and two stumpings, but conceded 19 byes in a rain-affected draw.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18619.html |title = Glamorgan v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Tallon's byes were 9.64% of the hosts' total, the highest percentage contribution made by byes to an innings on the tour.N-{{Ref label|percentage|4|b}} Saggers returned for the nine-wicket win over [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] and struggled, making a [[duck (cricket)|duck]]. Although he took two catches and a stumping, he conceded 28 byes, 9.56% of Warwickshire's total runs,{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18634.html |title = Warwickshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} the second highest percentage contribution of byes to a match total against Australia.N-{{Ref label|total|4|c}} Saggers was then rested for Australia's second match and second draw against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] as Tallon made three dismissals and conceded 23 byes.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18639.html |title = Lancashire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} In the non-first-class match against [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]], Tallon played purely as a batsman, while Saggers kept wicket. Saggers came in at 8/226 and made 22 to help Australia reach 273. He then made two stumpings and conceded four byes as the hosts reached 5/73 when rain ended the match.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18654.html |title = Durham v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} With Tallon fit again for the Fifth Test, Saggers was omitted as Australia won by an innings and 149 runs to complete a 4–0 series victory. == Later tour matches == Seven matches remained on Bradman's quest to complete an English tour without defeat. Tallon was rested for three consecutive matches against [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]],{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18674.html |title = Kent v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}} the [[Gentlemen of England cricket team|Gentlemen of England]],{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18684.html |title = Gentlemen v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2007-12-26}} and [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]], and Saggers kept wickets in all three fixtures; Australia won all three by an innings. Saggers made only eight as Australia scored 361 against Kent. He then conceded only two byes and took two catches and made two stumpings as the home side made 51 and 124. Saggers did not bat as Australia amassed 5/610 against the Gentlemen of England. He then took a catch and conceded 19 byes as Australia enforced the follow on and won. The match against Somerset was similar; Saggers did not bat in Australia's 5/560 declared, before making two stumpings and conceding eight byes.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18696.html |title = Somerset v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} In total, he made seven dismissals and conceded 29 byes in the six innings of the three matches. Saggers was rested as Tallon returned for the following match against the [[South of England cricket team|South of England]]. Tallon took three catches and conceded 13 byes before the match was washed out when the hosts were dismissed for 298.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18698.html |title = South of England v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} Australia's biggest challenge in the post-Test tour matches was against the [[H. D. G. Leveson-Gower|Leveson-Gower's]] [[11 (number)#In sports|XI]]. During the last tour in 1938, this team was effectively a full-strength England outfit, but this time Bradman insisted that only six current Test players be allowed to represent the hosts.Fingleton, pp. 207–209. Bradman then fielded a first-choice team;Perry (2005), pp. 253–254. the only difference from the Fifth Test team was [[Ian Johnson (cricketer)|Ian Johnson]]'s inclusion at the expense of [[Doug Ring]]. Saggers was left out as the match ended in a draw after multiple rain delays.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18706.html |title = H.D.G. Leveson-Gower's XI v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} The tour ended with two non-first-class matches against [[Scotland national cricket team|Scotland]]. In the first match, Tallon played as a batsman while Saggers kept wicket. Saggers scored only eight in Australia's 236 and then took two catches, three stumpings and conceded 13 byes in the innings victory.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18707.html |title = Scotland v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} In the second match in [[Aberdeen]], Saggers was rested as Australia completed another innings win.{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18709.html |title = Scotland v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate = 2008-12-18}} == Role == [[Image:Ron Saggers graph 1948.png|300px|right|thumb|A chart showing Saggers's batting performance during the tour. The runs scored per innings are represented by the bars, with the red bars being Test innings and the pink bars being other first-class innings. The blue line is the average of the five most recent innings and the dots indicate [[not out]]s.]] The reserve wicket-keeper, Saggers played in 17 first-class matches and scored 209 runs at an average of 23.22, including a career high score of 104 not out against Essex,Cashman, p. 267. 23 catches and 20 stumpings, also career records for one season. This compared with the first-choice gloveman Tallon, who scored 283 runs at 25.72.{{cite web| url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/records/averages/batting_bowling.html?class=4;id=1070;type=tour |publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |title=Batting and bowling averages Australia tour of England, Apr-Sep 1948 – First-class matches|accessdate=2008-12-10}} In all his matches on tour, Tallon missed 249 byes as Australia conceded 5331 runs, a bye percentage of 4.67%. In contrast, Saggers conceded 221 byes from the 6190 runs scored against Australia when he was behind the stumps, a percentage of 3.57%.N-{{Ref label|stumps|4|d}} In his 1950 book ''Farewell to cricket'', Bradman said of Saggers, "[he] had not quite the speed or agility of Tallon but could always be relied on for a solid performance. A most polished and unostentatious player."Bradman, p. 227. During the tour, Saggers had few opportunities with the bat, generally batting between [[batting order (cricket)|No. 8 and No. 10]],N-{{Ref label|stumps|4|d}} because Australia's frontline bowlers included the likes of [[Ray Lindwall]], [[Colin McCool]], [[Ian Johnson (cricketer)|Ian Johnson]] and [[Doug Ring]], who were all capable batsmen. Lindwall scored two Test centuries in his career, while McCool scored 18 first-class centuries, one in Tests. Johnson and Ring both scored more than 20 fifties at first-class level.Cashman, pp. 152, 175, 199, 258. As a result, many of the bowlers batted before he did. As Australia often won by an innings, and declared in the first innings on many occasions, Saggers only had 12 innings in his 17 first-class fixtures and was not out three times after his remaining partners had been dismissed. == See also == * [[1948 Ashes series]] ==Notes== ===Statistical notes===
